awd_titl_txt: NSFGEO-NERC: An Investigation into the Possible Co-evolution of Si and O Isotopes in Igneous Rocks and Minerals From the Hadean to Present
awd_abstract_narration:
The first Eon of Earth was named the "Hadean" because of the expectation that Earth would have remained hellish and inhospitable hundreds of millions of years after its formation about 4.56 billion years ago.  These models may have persisted, if it were not for the discovery of very ancient crystals from this Eon.  These crystals - or specifically the mineral zircon (ZrSiO4) - have ages that extend back to about 4.4 billion years in age, and thus represent a unique source of information about the earliest Earth.  The major goal of this research is to 'translate' the chemical information preserved within these crystals into physical and potentially planetary-wide constraints that specifically bear on water-rock interactions occurring on Earth before 4 billion years ago.  This was an intriguing time on Earth, because it is likely that the crust or its chemically weathered constituents played a role in the origin of life.  

The research proposed capitalizes on the knowledge that elements of O (oxygen) and Si (silicon) have multiple isotopes, and furthermore that the isotope ratios recorded in minerals, including zircon, may tell complementary stories of a larger puzzle about water-rock interactions that have occurred on our planet.  The investigation will begin by conducting: (i) high precision Si- and O- isotope measurements on well constrained rock and mineral samples; and (ii) high pressure/temperature experiments in the precision-controlled environment of the University of Rochester experimental geochemistry laboratory. This information will be used to interpret the Si- and O- isotope geochemistry of ancient zircon crystals to explore crustal recycling in a new manner. The broader impacts of this project come from the training of undergraduate and graduate students in high temperature/pressure experimental techniques and crystal synthesis, and isotope analysis using state-of-the-art mass spectrometers. The Rochester laboratory plans to host high school science teachers from the surrounding area to introduce them to the technology and the science used in this study.  These workshops expose science teachers to cutting edge science and technology and data that they can take back into their classrooms.

por.por_cntn:
We live on a dynamic planet where the physical and chemical characteristics of the interior and the near surface, including the oceans and atmosphere, are a  product of the initial conditions when our planet formed. To understand how our planet came to be in its present-day state, we need to peer back into earth's history to explore its evolution. This project takes the extreme view, by peering back over 4 billion years to the early stages of Earth, when continents, oceans, and perhaps life were emerging. To do this we use tiny crystals called zircon that have survived over 4 billion years on a dynamically active planet, while preserving chemistry from Earth’s early days. We explore how the isotopic composition of zircon can be used indirectly to investigate the types of rocks that were being weathered in low temperature environments. We also combine this investigation of ancient natural samples with state-of-the-art laboratory experiments and mass spectrometry.  In an attempt to limit possible formational regimes, we also measured trace constituents within zircon crystals (including rare earth elements) and combined those with experiments and models.  We produced the first ever experimental calibrations (focused on silicon isotope “separations” that occur between minerals at high temperature), and we also developed an entirely new analytical method for analyzing silicon and oxygen isotopes simultaneously. The latter produced the first ever measurements to reconstruct silicon and oxygen isotope history of the early earth before 4 billion years ago. To disseminate these results, we gave numerous guest lectures including invited talks at geochemistry conferences, local geological society talks, the Carl Sagan summer astrobiology workshop and department seminars at other geoscience institutions (e.g., Penn State, Rutgers University, Caltech).  This award also supported the training of graduate students (resulting in first author published papers by graduate students) as well as recently a defended PhD.  As a direct result of this award, the graduate student received training in mass spectrometry, scanning electron microscopy, and high-pressure high-temperature experimental geochemistry techniques.  All of these are directly applicable to careers in geology, chemistry, and material science.
